author: Jonathan Walker
title: Who should I vote for in the 2017 general election? The runner and riders are all here
text:
News Who should I vote for in the 2017 general election? The runner and riders are all here Here's a guide to the parties and what they believe in - so who will get your vote in this June's General Election? Share   General Election polls and projections: May 15 Share this video Get     
Deciding how to vote in the June 8 general election isn’t easy. 
Most candidates standing for election will be representing one of the political parties. 
And people usually vote based on which party they support. 
But there are exceptions. If there’s a candidate in your constituency who seems particularly impressive based on their commitment to the local area then you could consider backing them, regardless of which party they’re in. 
If not, then you might choose who to vote for based on their party: Who should I vote for in the 2017 general election? Conservatives 
The Conservatives , also known as the Tories, are currently in Government. 
They are led by Theresa May, the Prime Minister. So if they win this election then she will continue as Prime Minister. 
Mrs May actually opposed Brexit in last year’s EU referendum. But now, she says she’s going to ensure Brexit happens and is a success. 
Conservatives are traditionally seen as the party which backs business and wealthier people. 
But they’ve tried to change their image in recent years, for example by cutting taxes for working people on average and below-average salaries. 
Mrs May’s plans include allowing councils to build more council homes. Labour 
Labour are the main opposition party. 
In practice, if any party is going to replace the Conservatives as the Government, it can only be Labour. 
Their leader is Jeremy Corbyn. So if Labour wins the general election, Mr Corbyn will become Prime Minister. 
Labour also opposed Brexit in last year’s referendum, but now say they respect the result of the vote and want Brexit to be a success. 
Labour is usually seen as the party most committed to helping the poorest people in society, and to funding public services such as the NHS. 
And Labour says it plans to increase NHS funding by £37 billion over five years if it wins the general election, funded partly by putting up taxes for people on salaries of £80,000 a year or more. Liberal Democrats 
The Liberal Democrats , also known as the Lib Dems, have traditionally been seen as the “third party” in the UK. 
That means they don’t have enough MPs to form a government, but they do have enough to be important. 
But the Lib Dems lost a lot of MPs at the last election, in 2015. This seems to be because they were part of a Coalition government with the Conservatives from 2010 to 2015, and some of their traditional supporters were unhappy about this. 
They are often seen as a “centre” party, somewhere in between Labour and the Conservatives. 
They also have a history of supporting equal rights for minorities and civil liberties. 
Their current leader is Tim Farron. 
Liberal Democrat policies include making cannabis legal, so you can buy it in shops. 
They also want to have a second referendum on Brexit, giving people the chance to vote to stay in the EU after all. Read More Voting survey reveals the Conservatives could take safe Labour seat in the North East UKIP 
The United Kingdom Independence Party , usually known as UKIP, campaigned for the UK to leave the EU back when the other parties, and most of the media, dismissed the idea as silly. 
Their leader for many years was Nigel Farage, who became very well known. 
Now they are led by Paul Nuttall. 
Their policies include banning people from covering their faces in public. This would include a ban on face veils worn by some Muslim women. Green Party 
The Green Party is known as a party with a strong commitment to protecting the environment. 
But it has policies on other issues too. It’s usually seen as a left-wing party, although the Greens call themselves “progressive”. 
Policies include building 500,000 socially rented homes to provide new, affordable homes to thousands of families. And they want to scrap tuition fees paid by university students. 
The Green Party has two leaders - Caroline Lucas and Jonathan Bartley. Like us on Facebook
